conclusion: Determine when the particle is farthest from the starting point based on the acceleration-time graph.
Acceleration increases linearly from 0 to a0 from t=0 to t=t0/2.
Acceleration decreases linearly from a0 to 0 from t=t0/2 to t=t0.
Acceleration decreases linearly from 0 to -a0 from t=t0 to t=3t0/2.
Acceleration increases linearly from -a0 to 0 from t=3t0/2 to t=2t0.
Velocity is the integral of acceleration with respect to time.
From t=0 to t=t0/2, velocity v(t) = (a0/t0) t^2.
At t=t0/2, velocity v(t0/2) = a0 t0/4.
From t=t0/2 to t=t0, velocity v(t) = a0 t0/2 - (a0 t^2)/(2t0).
At t=t0, velocity v(t0) = a0 t0/2.
From t=t0 to t=3t0/2, velocity v(t) = a0 t0/2 - (a0/t0) (t^2 - 2t0 t + t0^2).
